title-group.article-title: Confirmation of the recognition of Culiseta (Culiseta) indica Edwards, 1920 as a distinct species based on integrated morphological and molecular data

sec.title: N/A
sec.p:
Confirmation of the recognition of
Culiseta ( Culiseta ) indica Edwards, 1920
as a distinct species based on integrated morphological and molecular data
R. NATARAJAN 1,2* , S. GOPALAKRISHNAN 1,3 , H.D. TALIB 1,4 , N. PRADEEP KUMAR 1,5 , A.N. SHRIRAM 1,6 , ASHWANI KUMAR 1,7 & P. JAMBULINGAM 1,8

Indian Council of Medical Research – Vector Control Research Centre, Puducherry 605006, India .

sec.title: Abstract
sec.p:
Theobaldia indica Edwards, 1920
, classified as a subspecies of
Culiseta ( Culiseta ) alaskaensis ( Ludlow, 1906 )
, was recently restored to its original species status, as
Culiseta ( Culiseta ) indica (Edwards)
, based on comprehensive assessments of morphological, ecological and distributional data. Predating the recognition of
indica
as a separate species, we collected specimens of this nominal taxon in the Western Himalayan region of India during 2015–2017, and used morphological and molecular studies to assess its taxonomic status. Our detailed examination of adult morphology, male genitalia and larval characteristics revealed significant distinctions between putative
Cs. alaskaensis alaskaensis
and
Cs. alaskaensis indica
, and sequencing of the barcode region of the mitochondrial COI gene yielded a Kimura 2 parameter genetic distance of 5.9% between them, well above the standard 2‒3% commonly accepted to indicate separate species. These results strongly support the formal recognition of
Cs. indica
as a separate species. Furthermore, the geographical distribution of
Cs. indica
provides additional evidence in support of its species status.

sec.title: N/A
sec.p:
Key words: mosquito , taxonomy ,
Culiseta
,
indica
,
India
, DNA barcoding

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
described
Theobaldia indica
from a single adult male collected in Bakloh, Punjab, Himachal Pradesh State , India . The species has been recorded in various high-altitude locations in Haryana , Himachal Pradesh and Uttar Pradesh States (
,
).
, during mosquito studies in the former USSR, reclassified
Theobaldia indica
as a subspecies of
Theobaldia alaskaensis Ludlow, 1906
. Subsequently,
transferred
alaskaensis indica
to the genus
Culiseta Felt, 1904
.

Prior to the work of
, we had collected immature stages of
Culiseta
in the Ladakh region in the Western Himalayas, India . Through morphological examination using available taxonomic keys and comprehensive comparisons with existing descriptions, we identified link-reared adults as
Cs . alaskaensis indica
. Additionally, we conducted molecular analyses of the subspecies using the DNA barcoding method of species identification.The results of our morphological studies and comparative DNA sequence analyses of the mitochondrial COI gene are presented here.

sec.title: Material and methods
sec.p:
DNA extraction, amplification and sequencing .
Two legs from one side of each of six specimens were removed for molecular characterization using DNA barcoding methodology ( Table 1 ). DNA was extracted following standard methodology and subjected to PCR for amplification of the mitochondrial COI gene as described by
. The amplified fragments were purified, sequenced and genetic analysis performed according to the standard DNA barcoding protocol (
). The Neighbor-Joining (NJ) method was used to generate phylogenetic trees (
;
) using the bioinformatics software MEGA X (Tamura et al . 2021). Interior branch tests with 1,000 simulations were chosen to determine the statistical significance of the clades. Genetic distances were estimated by using the Kimura 2-parameter (K2P) method (
). The COI sequences were submitted to GenBank , accession numbers OM102959‒OM102964. The sequences were compared with sequences identified as
Cs. alaskaensis
in GenBank using the Basic Local Alignment Search Tool (BLAST, available at http://blast.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/Blast.cgi) under default parameters. Sequences for
Cs. alaskaensis
from different geographical locations deposited in the GenBank were included in the phylogenetic analysis. The COI sequences of
Culex tritaeniorhynchus Giles, 1901
from India generated by us were included as the outgroup
.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: *Localities in the Leh District, Jammu & Kashmir State, India.

sec.title: Results
sec.p:
Morphological assessment . The two nominal forms,
alaskaensis
and
indica
, were distinguished from other species in the nominate subgenus of
Culiseta
by the presence of broad pale bands on the hindtarsi and the absence of subapical pale bands on the femora. It was obvious from published descriptions that
indica
was similar to
alaskaensis
, but they are distinguishable from each other in the adult and larval stages.

Examination of 11 females of
indica
from various locations in India revealed the following distinctions from
alaskaensis
.
Thorax
: Scutal integument pale brown, clothed with narrow yellowish scales, some specimens with indistinct spots of narrow yellowish scales, not intermixed with white scales ( Table 2 ). In contrast, the scutal integument of
alaskaensis
is dark brown or black, with white scales along with brown scales forming a spot.
Wing
: Scales narrow, dark brown, light to moderate sprinkling of pale scales along the costa, subcosta, vein R 1 and base of vein CuA; membrane not definitely clouded, but with an aggregation of scales at the base of vein R 3 and the bifurcations of veins R 2+3 and M 1+2 , giving the wing a slightly spotted appearance; only cross vein M 3+4 without scales; a tuft of yellowish setae present basally on the ventral side of the subcosta ( Fig. 2F ). In contrast, in
alaskaensis
, wing scales narrow, dark, some pale scales intermixed on the costa, subcosta and vein R 1 ; scales dense and dark, producing spots at the origin of vein R 2+3 , at crossveins, at forks of veins R 2+3 and M 1+2 , and the middle of vein CuA.
Legs
: Scattering of pale scales on all legs and basal white bands on tarsomeres 2‒4 in
indica
and
alaskaensis
.
Abdomen
: Pale basal bands on terga indistinguishable from those of
alaskaensis
.

Nineteen fourth-instar larvae and 10 larval exuviae of
indica
collected in India were examined.
Head
: Pale brown (dark brown or black in
alaskaensis
); length shorter than width; seta 4-C usually with 3(2–6) branches (usually 3, rarely 4, branches in
alaskaensis
); seta 5-C with 6–9 long aciculate branches, inserted well posterior to seta 4-C; seta 6-C with 3 aciculate branches, rarely 4 branches on one side, longer than seta 5-C, middle branch longer and stronger than the others, 1 specimen with 3 branches the same length (usually 2 branches in alaskaensi s); seta 7-C with 9–13 aciculate branches. Antenna : Distinctly shorter than head, with spicules; seta 1-A inserted about

DNA barcode analysis . The NJ analysis of the COI sequences obtained from the Himalayan specimens and the COI sequences of
Cs. alaskaensis
available in GenBank generated a tree with two distinct clades ( Fig. 3 ), one comprised of the former specimens (
Cs. indica
) and the other consisting of the sequences of
Cs. alaskaensis
(with bootstrap clade support values of 99% and 96%, respectively). The K2P genetic distance between the two groups was calculated to be 5.9%, indicating that they belong to two different species.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p:
Characteristics that distinguish the adults of
Cs. indica
from those of
Cs. alaskaensis
are summarized in Table 2 . These findings agree with the observations of
,
,
,
,
and
. Recent studies on the prespiracular, postpronotal and prealar setae of the thorax (
) have revealed statistically significant differences between
Cs. alaskaensis
and
Cs. indica
. Our observations on the three groups of thoracic setae largely corresponded with the findings of Khalin & Aibulatov (see Table 2 ). Based on adult and larval features, we are confident that the two morphological forms are separate species, which supports the decision of
to upgrade
indica
to species status based on morphological information.

Within the topography of the Leh District in the Ladakh region, characterized by high plains, deep valleys and mountains with limited or no vegetation, we only collected the immature stages of
Cs. indica
in areas of plains, which is similar to the observations of Maslow (1989). In comparison,
Cs. alaskaensis
is associated with forested areas (
). The distinct habitat preferences of the two forms provide further ecological support for the elevation of
indica
to species status by Harbach & Wilkerson.

The allopatric distributions of
Cs. alaskaensis
and
Cs. indica
correspond with their independent species status: the distribution of
Cs. alaskaensis
includes Asia eastward from the European part of Russia to northeastern China , Canada and the U.S.A. , whereas
Cs. indica
is recorded in the Caucasus region (mainly comprised of Armenia , Azerbaijan , Georgia and parts of southeastern Russia ), Kazakhstan and Central Asia, with additional reports from northern India , Iran , Pakistan and Ukraine (see
: fig. 60).

The sequencing of the mitochondrial COI gene has become a dependable method for identifying species of various animal groups (
). The K2P estimate of genetic distance and the phylogenetic analyses of COI sequences reported here confirm that the two forms previously considered to be subspecies of
Cs. alaskaensis
actually are distinct monophyletic taxa. The K2P values between the two clades shown in Fig. 3 exceed the 2–3% threshold established for the recognition of separate species (
). Additionally, the strong branch support for the two clades, 99% for
indica
and 96% for
alaskaensis
, supports the monophyly of the two species.
stated that “we think it likely that molecular data will show it [
alaskaensis
] is a complex of species.” In our study, we did not find any indication of a complex of species, but further study of material collected throughout the distribution of
Cs. alaskaensis
may provide evidence of a complex. In conclusion, the cumulative morphological, ecological, distributional and molecular data strongly supports the recognition of
Cs . indica
as a species distinct from
Cs. alaskaensis
.

sec.title: Acknowledgements
sec.p: We are extremely grateful to the editor for providing valuable suggestions for improving the manuscript. We are also thankful to anonymous reviewers for their suggestions that have improved the manuscript. Our thanks to Dr Manju Rahi, Director, ICMR- Vector Control Research Centre, Puducherry for her support and encouragement. We also thank Dr K. H. Raju, Principal Technical Officer, for his help in the preparation of the map and N. Krishnaraj, Laboratory Technician A, for his support in the field.
